item.label: rotten
item.content: You could get angry that a guy like this even got a chance. Or you could just forget about him, and move on to something worthwhile.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: When it comes to rowdiness and raunch, it's right up there with Animal House and Porky's -- and beyond -- but the writers and director Bob Gosse know how to turn excess, self-indulgence, selfishness and chauvinism back on itself with blowtorch impact.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie plays out like a watered-down and far less comical version of The Hangover, without the likable characters and the crazy fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Speaking generously for the sake of everyone involved in this mess, let's hope the title proves prophetic.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell is the perfect cautionary tale for any frat boy who considers making a film based on the phrase, \"Dude, remember that one time?\"

item.label: fresh

item.content: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell is the Armageddon of gross-out sex comedies.

item.content: Kurosawa performs a tour-de-force in keeping a dramatic thread throughout and avoiding the mawkish.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If you have never seen it, you should. If you have seen it before, your admiration will only increase.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Take a look at this film. At the very least, it'll prompt you to assess your balance of work and life, and you may find yourself putting in for a little vacation time.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There has never been a smarter, more compassionate film about imminent death.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Often heavy-handed but never less than heartfelt, Ikiru (To Live) is universal in its thrust and startlingly astute in its narrative engineering.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: Very little that's clever, romantic or witty in this formulaic romp.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The most shocking thing about I Think I Love My Wife isn't the language, the sex, or the racial humor. It's the fact that it's not a funny movie. At all.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I Think I Love My Wife has little to say and it doesn't have enough laughs to work as pure comedy. Rock the writer/director isn't doing Rock the actor any favors here, nor is he doing many for the audience.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As uneven as I Think I Love My Wife often is, it still has an emotional resonance lacking in most films about relationships. By dealing with temptation in even a quasi-realistic way, it affirms that, like comedy, monogamy is hard.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Rock fails to develop the characters caught in their conjugal and singleton traps. As usual, his observational humor zings (and stings) -- but this is a movie, not stand-up.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Rock is so fixed on crude jokes, he neglects to create realistic characters and a story that's compelling to follow.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Chris Rock, who famously mocked Jude Law's movie career at the Oscars, ought to watch out for his own after his second dud in a row as an actor-director, the screamingly unfunny romantic comedy I Think I Love My Wife.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For each joke that is fresh, there are at least three that fall thuddingly flat.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Rock's defining comic characteristic is his no-nonsense honesty, tackling awkward issues head-on with bold, hostile, uproarious insights. Playing a milquetoast, he's tossed away his best weapon.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I Think I Love My Wife is about as entertaining as reading someone else's divorce settlement.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The picture is worth catching for the delicate and toxic nuances of Rudd's performance.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though the script doesn't always rise to their level, I Love You, Man is more than worth seeing for the chemistry between the shambling Segel and the endlessly inventive Rudd.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a hilarious comedy made even more successful because so much of the satire seems fresh.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The marvelous thing about John Hamburg's new comedy, I Love You, Man, is that rather than conforming to fit into some preexisting trend, it recognizes and even exalts in the reality that close male friendships can be a source of confusion and awkwardness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Luckily, the cast is so winning, that the occasional sexism can be ignored, and the off-the-wall pop culture name-checks (Lou Ferrigno, as a guest star?) enjoyed.

item.content: In almost every major detail and minor plot hiccup, the sweet, vulgar, hilariously awkward I Love You, Man follows Ye Olde Formulae for standard romantic comedies.

item.content: It's a one-joke pony, but director John Hamburg and his screenwriters manage to stretch it to nearly two hours of hilarity and quasi-profundity.

item.content: At best, I Love You Phillip Morris may be hailed as a necessary step in Hollywood's fearful crawl toward sexual evenhandedness; the film upholds the constitutional right of every gay man to be as much of a liar, a crook, and a creep as the rest of us.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Nolan, like Cobb, is an assiduous extractor, and he knows how to wow audiences. But scaling big and thinking big are not the same thing. And dark, just because it's dark, isn't more artistic than light.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Like his protagonist, Nolan excels as an implanter of subversive ideas. This time, alas, he didn't dig quite deep enough for them to take root.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Inception is that rare film that can be enjoyed on superficial and progressively deeper levels, a feat that uncannily mimics the mind-bending journey its protagonist takes.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.content: Pic comes on like a sledgehammer, and there's even a taste of vulgarity and senseless excess not apparent in Raiders.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film betrays no human impulse higher than that of a ten-year-old boy trying to gross out his baby sister by dangling a dead worm in her face.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Set years before the events of Raiders of the Lost Ark, Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom is sillier, darkly violent and a bit dumbed down, but still great fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Part of the trouble is that anything clearly does go, including the slender hold on credibility that Raiders managed to maintain.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The kind of movie where your date is always grabbing your forearm in a viselike grip, as unbearable excitement unfolds on the screen. After the movie is over, you've had a great time but your arm is black-and-blue for a week.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If you like to go to weddings of humdrum people you don't know, you won't want to miss Indian Summer.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Just too pat, too predictable and too generic.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A mish-mash of mediocre formulas.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a story more interested in tone and mood than in big plot points.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie doesn't stick together in one's head; this thing is like some junky fairground show -- a chamber of horrors with skeletons that jump up.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Irwin Allen, the Busby Berkeley of natural disasters and other people's troubles, teams up with John Guillermin, a competent if undistinguished action director.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The Towering Inferno is one of the greatest disaster pictures made, a personal and professional triumph for producer Irwin Allen.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A starry cast share out roles that are less like characters than places in a lifeboat.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You may not come out of the theater with any important ideas about American architecture or enterprise, but you will have had a vivid, completely safe nightmare.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Like a bat to the head, it's not too subtle, but you can't help but watch.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Quentin Tarantino seems to be hanging on to a lost world of moviemaking. He may be nuts. But he's a nut who cares.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Its biggest flaw, though, for those who care about such things, may be its moral attitude. That might seem a stodgy thing to bring up in the context of a Quentin Tarantino movie, but it takes such center stage that it needs to be examined.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Tarantino's vigorously accomplished 'Inglourious Basterds'

item.label: fresh
item.content: Landa is such a wily and despicable concoction that, in movie terms, he's almost impossible not to like. And therein lies part of my problem with this movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I'm tempted to say Tarantino has done it again, but I doubt anyone has ever done anything like his dazzlingly original World War II movie, Inglourious Basterds.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's these fine sequences that can make you truly regret Tarantino's snarky, in-joke impulses, not to mention his arrogant -- perhaps even dangerous -- lack of concern with the story's moral dimensions.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Will Basterds polarize audiences? That's a given. But for anyone professing true movie love, there's no resisting it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The picture contains all the things his fans like about Tarantino -- the wit, the audacity, the sudden violence -- but this movie's emotional core and bigness of spirit are new.

item.label: rotten
item.content: War reduced to pop entertainment should at least be easy to swallow, but this stuff keeps getting stuck in our craw. The trash that Tarantino used to elevate he now imitates.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Tarantino's signature nastiness and his juvenile delight in shocking the audience undercut the movie's larger purpose.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Scenes like the showdown in the tavern and the movie-premiere finale are as imaginative, energetic and, in their own weird, brutal way, beautiful as cinema gets.

item.label: rotten
item.content: All the trademark Tarantino flourishes are here -- the joyous splaying of gore; the self-referential dialogue; the artful artificiality and the juxtaposition of humor and violence -- but they don't add up to much.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Simply another testament to his movie love. The problem is that by making the star attraction of his latest film a most delightful Nazi, one whose smooth talk is as lovingly presented as his murderous violence, Mr. Tarantino has polluted that love.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For all its visual bravura and occasional bursts of antic inspiration, it feels trivial, the work of a kid who can't stop grabbing his favorite shiny plaything.

item.label: fresh
item.content: One of the best performances of the decade in one of the most entertaining movies of the year.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A bland, occasionally phlegmatic pastiche of cliches and dull encounters.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Ultimately, this workplace fairy tale creates its own cheer. When its time is up, you'll feel like you've been in good company.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If the rest of the movie were as good as Scarlett, we might give a damn.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A richly satisfying and darkly funny movie about, of all places, a workplace.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Feels like a movie written by and for marketing types -- Quaid and Marg Helgenberger (as his wife) to appeal to baby boomers, and Grace and Johansson for Generation Y. That's a business strategy, not a movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A rare species: a feel-good movie about big business. It's about a corporate culture that tries to be evil and fails.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It is clever and thoughtful and has the added benefit of being about people you may recognize as fellow wage earners, for better or worse.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Topher Grace, Dennis Quaid and Scarlett Johansson all turn in fine performances. But they all seem to tread water, waiting for the next big wave that doesn't come.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Makes the word mainstream seem a little less pejorative. It's a broadly appealing comedy that's neither stupid nor vulgar and, as such, deserving of praise.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It is at once funny, awkward and true, which puts it in rare company, indeed.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As corporate comedy-dramas go, Company is cheerful and easy to watch but surprisingly inept in the telling.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Before it hits the rails in a third act that has the odor of a test-marketing compromise, Weitz's film moves at an engaging gallop.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie's most poignant moments remind you that for every rising star in the corporate world, there's a dutiful old-timer who is suddenly, and sometimes unfairly, deemed expendable.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It goes on and on, the slowness exacerbated by Preminger's customary long takes and by the endless parade of star cameos.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Spencer Tracy does his cuddly curmudgeon turn as Clarence Darrow; it's a lazy, vague performance, but its wit provides the only crack of light in the film's somber, gray overcast.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Tolerably gripping in its old-fashioned way, thanks chiefly to old pro performances from Tracy and March as the rival lawyers and ideologists.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Considering it doesn't star Maggie Smith or Judi Dench, it's surprising how mature and moving this female-focused drama is.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I think one reason this movie is so appealing is that it's the anti-Sex and the City-its earnestness and relative lack of rank bawdiness or cynicism seem novel in the present pop-culture atmosphere.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie gets much, much better as it goes along.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Very well written. All the supporting performances are good.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Although In Her Shoes aims to rub along, with that scuffed worldliness which Hanson has made his own, it keeps bumping into the archness of the romantic-domestic genre.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There'd be nothing wrong with this if the film 'fessed up to its kitschy soul. Instead, it pretends to be the high-minded drama it's not.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Forsaking all art and subtlety, something he used to display in abundance, Hanson has chosen to adapt a Jennifer Weiner novel that is so light, it should come with weights attached to keep it from floating away.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Collette's performance is so full of juice and the beneficiary of good dialogue that Diaz's may end up being underrated.

item.label: rotten
item.content: In Her Shoes is aimed squarely at a demographic -- grown-up women -- who aren't often catered to by Hollywood, and it's competent and sometimes charming. But there's a soap-opera blandness to it that even the gifted cast can't overcome.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The characters seem authentic -- until the chick-flick template distorts them.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Try on these Shoes. Even if you don't like the style, you will love where they take you.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A genuinely heartfelt look at sibling rivalry, and the bonds (and battles) that sisters are heir to.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Schmaltzy, but reasonably entertaining.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In Her Shoes may be corny, but its tenderness is genuine, and the movie's affection for its characters is awfully contagious.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Never lurked a Chick Flick that looked fairer on the urge to talk things out. Never lurked one with a smarter cast or a more cluttered screenplay, full of mirth and sorrow.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A bungled mess that spends an hour creating two characters whose lives are about as believable as a successful ambush set by Wile E. Coyote for the Road Runner.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A clunky flick that doesn't think at all, and ends up aping the worst traits of both siblings: Far too big and way too shallow, it's a bloated lightweight of a movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It would be a terrible shame if half the population didn't see it because the film was labeled unjustly.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a chick flick for non-chicks too, one of those movies that makes you laugh and cry and leaves you feeling satisfied and drained and vaguely embarrassed for having such a good time.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's difficult to think of a Hanson film in which the performances are wanting, and Shoes is no exception.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The aesthetics of Inkheart are part of what make it such a surprisingly enjoyable experience to watch.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Has] plenty of thrills, a smart although oft-confusing script, delightful scenery-chewing scenes from stalwarts like Helen Mirren, Jim Broadbent and Andy Serkis, and a gorgeous high-concept visual style.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Seemingly intended as a celebration of the power of books, it's an occasionally incoherent, sleep-inducing picture that reduces narrative to mere mechanics.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Over and over again, characters in Inkheart wax eloquent on the power of books. But there's nothing in the movie as haunting or as compelling as the sound they make when they speak for themselves.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A flea market of fairy tales and hocus-pocus, Inkheart makes as much sense as an inkblot.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The overqualified cast gives its all, but logical lapses and sober-sided direction siphon off the fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie never achieves the sort of transporting fantasy that formed the backbone of the novel: The limitless potential for adventure and excitement that books provide, given physical form when transplanted into our reality.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film's storybook Alpine vistas are lovely to behold, and bits of humor pop out in welcome moments. Other than that, it never quite springs to life as intended -- not in your kitchen, and not on screen.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As an adventure flick, Inkheart is not all that adventurous. It goes to places and falls on tropes that many fantasy films -- most notably but not exclusively the Lord of the Rings trilogy -- have covered.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Even if it can't quite conjure up the movie magic it intends, Inkheart does serve as public service announcement promoting literacy. And as such, your kids could do a lot worse at the cineplex.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Much of this comes across as a labor of love, with a classy cast frolicking in Iain Softley's whimsical direction of a lushly imagined adaptation by David Lindsay-Abaire.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's handsomely mounted, with supporting turns by Helen Mirren as the girl's flinty aunt and Jim Broadbent as the author of the book that caused so much fuss.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Inkheart illustrates an obvious problem with making a movie about the joys of reading when the movie made is labored and sludgy looking: Why bother seeing it if you can stay home and read a book instead?

item.label: rotten
item.content: Inkheart was a busy, crowded, hugely successful book to start with....the film version retains nearly all of author Cornelia Funke's story complications. It's a mixed bag and a serious load for a movie to carry.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A movie that can produce the image of Helen Mirren astride a unicorn has some claim on the audience's interest, and a movie that can make that image seem perfectly uninteresting is in some serious trouble.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Inkheart is a valentine to books mainly by negative example -- the leaps of imagination it doesn't achieve.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A kids' adventure movie can be a lot of things -- wild and woolly, loosey-goosey, full of foolishness -- but they should never be shabby. And that's the best word for Inkheart.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Inkheart may not be rotten to the core -- instead of maggots, the fantasy adventure seethes with good intentions -- but the overripeness of its special effects can't be overstated.

item.content: In Love and War is at its best photographing stationary objects, such as architecture, trees and bedridden soldiers -- not exactly what one hopes for from a movie portraying such a vital force as Ernest Hemingway.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The plot is standard fantasy-adventure pulp, though director Joe Dante has so many screwball things going on in it that the comedy all but overwhelms the formulaic line of action.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Short has infinitely more possibilities and makes the most of them, coming into his own as a screen personality as a mild-mannered little guy who rises to an extraordinary situation.

item.label: rotten
item.content: While the anatomical special effects are imaginative enough, the manic rather than magical tone fails to achieve the sense of awe that made Fantastic Voyage -- clearly this film's inspiration -- so fascinating.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It has been made in a style best described as enthusiastic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Here is an absurd, unwieldy, overplotted movie that nevertheless is entertaining - and some of the fun comes from the way the plot keeps laying it on.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's an easy-to-get-along-with movie -- bouncy, rabbity fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Innerspace is significant for one thing -- the establishment of Martin Short as the funniest new kid on the Hollywood block. Too bad that's not enough for the sensation-a-second makers of Innerspace.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The elegance, attention to detail, the invention and expertise all ensure that the movie's never less than visually breathtaking.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Occasional passages of shell-cracking egghead overload aside, there's no getting past Innocence's astounding visual power.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The effect of so much pretension and so many lovely images eventually becomes soporific.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Praiseworthy for its concepts and aesthetics, yet it is too theory-heavy and action-shy, clumped with philosophical tangents and scholarly reference points.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Solemnly questioning issues of science and metaphysics, it creates a spell that's a unique blend of the ominous and the sensual.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Its intentions aren't as clear as they should be, but it's clearly the work of a deep-thinking artist with a fearful concern for a future in which the nature of humanity is entirely uncertain.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Doesn't match the weight of its predecessor, or really add anything necessary to the saga, but it doesn't hurt the body of work, either.

item.label: fresh
item.content: More vital than most police procedurals, fusing the metaphysical and the scientific into a pulp yarn with a gentle but bruising philosophical kick.

item.label: rotten
item.content: While the visuals are at times stylish, Ghost suffers most from a distinct lack of anything, well, cinematic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Innocence doesn't just reveal a wealth of visual enchantments; it restates the case that there can and should be more to feature-length animations than cheap jokes, bathos and pandering.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A rehash that takes a timely theme, mankind's obsession with technology, and bloats it to the point of incomprehension, cramming meaning into dialogue that has none.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a meaning-of- everything flick -- with a superficial plot about murderous androids -- yet its main characters are interesting because of their connection to each other rather than the metaphysical.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A stunning work of animation artistry and a compelling metaphysical inquiry into what constitutes humanity and machine.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A revelation, a challenging yet enlightening journey into the depths of creativity and imagination.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Regrettably, all too often the tone lurches from stylish suspense to smart-ass in-jokiness and silly slapstick.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [An] overlong, overproduced spectacle.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Innocent Blood is an uncomfortable marriage of vampires and mobsters; it doesn't work on either the supernatural or the criminal level.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Like one of the victims, Innocent Blood feels about five quarts low.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [A] distinctly enjoyable offering.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mr. King's direction, occasionally, is inspired, and the photography has unusual style and dramatic impact.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: There is something to be said for a movie that may end up preaching, for a change, to the unconverted. If only the laughs were bigger, smarter and more frequent than they are.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The premise is older than the pilot for Three's Company, and just as unfunny.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry manages to insult gays, straights, men, women, children, African-Americans, Asians, pastors, mailmen, insurance adjusters, firemen, doctors -- and fans of show music. That's championship stuff.

item.label: rotten
item.content: With a tacked-on PC message and leaden attempts at humor, I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry is a movie that gives marriage, homosexuality, friendship, firefighters, children and nearly everything else a bad name.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Chuck and Larry remains something close to remarkable: an Adam Sandler movie that manages to be crude and caring in equal measure. In the multiplex, this is called progress.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For the most part, I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry plods along predictably, well-intentioned but only sporadically entertaining.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If there were a Straight Lack-of-Pride Parade, I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry could be the grand marshal. The movie isn't insulting to homosexuals but to comedy.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Does anybody laugh at this stuff anymore?

item.label: fresh
item.content: Chuck and Larry proves that even the silliest comedy can offer important food for thought.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The sad thing is that this could have been really good.

item.label: rotten
item.content: In the spirit of uncivil unions, I now denounce you, Chuck and Larry.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It all boils down to a horrible waste of talent.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie is often stupid. But coming from an industry institutionally terrified of being honest about its own sexuality, it feels brave, going a step further than 'not that there's anything wrong with that.'

item.label: rotten
item.content: Sporadically funny, casually sexist, blithely racist and about as visually sophisticated as a parking-garage surveillance video.

item.label: rotten
item.content: An equal-opportunity offender, slapping right wingers on the wrist while, much to said right wingers' expectations, reducing homosexuality to its lowest common denominators.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry works hard at not being offensive. It just doesn't work hard enough at being good.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There are gags here that may be older than the film's stars.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Adam Sandler and Kevin James play courageous Brooklyn firefighters and best friends in this comedy that seems designed to be as bad as it can be.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You'll need a clear head to follow this impressive and angry American doc about the financial meltdown...

item.label: fresh
item.content: This scathing expose should be enough to alarm people all over the political spectrum.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Wall Street owns Washington. You might think you know this, but \"Inside Job\" makes you feel the enormity of it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Whether it's parsing the definition of a derivative or detailing the bad faith of major financial institutions, the new documentary Inside Job approaches its deconstruction of the financial meltdown with laserlike focus.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Ferguson] can get to a story later but provide so much more context that his film seems definitive.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Inside Job is densely packed with information, charts and graphics, but the film is propelled by an angry, fiery pulse...

item.label: fresh
item.content: A trained economist might challenge his analysis, but there's no question that Ferguson, who holds a PhD in political science and is a former business consultant, is a formidable interviewer.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It should have you leaving the theatre in the same angry mood that fuelled Toronto Mayor-elect Rob Ford's \"Stop the Gravy Train!\" mantra.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A damning indictment of the individuals and institutions who made money while customers lost their shirts.

item.label: fresh
item.content: f you've been affected by the bottom dropping out of the economy -- who hasn't? -- but didn't know where to target your disappointment, your frustration, your rage, Inside Job gives you the answer:

item.label: fresh
item.content: Inside Job traces the history of the crisis and its implications with exceptional lucidity, rigor and righteous indignation.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's such a thing as smart angry, and such a thing as stupid angry, and after seeing Inside Job, audiences will be smart angry.

item.label: fresh
item.content: After watching Charles Ferguson's powerhouse documentary about the global economic crisis, you will more than understand what went down -- you will be thunderstruck and boiling with rage.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is no dry economics lesson; it is a vital wake-up call.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a work of sustained, nonpartisan rage. Its anger is always simmering, never all-consuming. Ferguson knows what it is he wants to say, and the movie goes about its point-making with lawyerly precision.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Ferguson takes the time to be clear about what he's arguing, and whom he's blaming for what. With just two feature-length talking-heads docs, Ferguson has done a great deal to restore confidence in the genre.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An angry, well-argued documentary about how the American financial industry set out deliberately to defraud the ordinary American investor.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Indignation is often the most self-deluding of emotions; this movie has the rare gifts of lucid passion and informed rage.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [A] wily thriller, which revitalizes a familiar premise by turning it inside out.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As unexpected as some of its plot twists is the fact that this unapologetic genre movie was directed by Spike Lee, who has never sold himself as Mr. Entertainment. But here it is, a Spike Lee joint that's downright fun.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A slick, kinetic and relatively straightforward -- which is to say enjoyably twisty-turny -- tranche of cat-and-mouse procedural.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I gloried in the sheer spectacle of Jodie Foster as Madeline White, an exquisitely groomed, fearlessly feline fixer striding on her high heels and her high horse into one supposedly perilous situation after another.

item.label: fresh

item.content: Even past the midway point, it's all working -- it's taut, it's funny, it's trenchant, it's stylish. And then it isn't.

item.label: fresh

item.content: Exceptionally well written with clever twists and witty dialogue by first-time screenwriter Russell Gewirtz, Inside Man is adroitly executed by director Spike Lee.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Intercutting post-robbery interrogation scenes with the action at hand, makes Inside Man a substantial and satisfying affair.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a leisurely stroll through the caper genre, with twists aplenty.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Lee seems less interested in scoring easy sociological points than ratcheting up the stakes of Gewirtz's cunning heist scenario, which offers little in the way of wiggle room for latecomers.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Inside Man is the sort of movie that makes you think. The big star heist thriller is coiled in tricky turns of plot.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Inside Man, a crackling, twisty thriller about a bank heist that shows he [Spike Lee] can make an expensive, mainstream movie that's every bit as well-crafted as the personal, arty films to which he has devoted most of his career.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.content: Luminous in The Kids are All Right and Alice in Wonderland, Wasikowska makes drab seem rad in director Cary Fukunaga's insightful rendering of Bronte's gothic love story, a new classic version of this oft-told tale.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mia Wasikowska, from Australia, is a relative newcomer who must essentially carry \"Jane Eyre,\" and succeeds with restraint, expressing a strong moral compass.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A better barometer for the necessity of Cary Fukunaga's film, however, might be its less-than-literate box office competition. Applying that consideration, maybe we do need this Jane Eyre after all.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It has passion all right -- in the stylistics. Those star-crossed love birds Jane and Rochester are no match for the tracking shots and throbbing violins.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a tailor-made role for Cube -- not surprising, considering he wrote the script -- and he plays it with his familiar mix of brash-talking bluster and brow-knitting frustration.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film's strong suit is vagueness, presenting combat as a semi-surreal state of ignorant expectation and dislocated experience: these warriors loll in the desert awaiting action or trying to make sense of its consequences.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Jarhead is utterly predictable (boys endure tough training; boys encounter another culture and are baffled), studded with first-rate performances.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a very strong film with really good performances.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What's so good about the movie is Gyllenhaal's refusal to show off; he doesn't seem jealous of the camera's attention when it goes to others and is content, for long stretches, to serve simply as a prism though which other young men can be observed.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Director Sam Mendes' third screen outing pretty well nails Swofford's tone, which was mordant without being disrespectful, and, in fact, is begrudgingly reverent of the Corps.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Jarhead makes its points less obviously than most war films, and with more brains than blood.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The best war movies -- and this one, despite its being overlong and repetitive, is among them -- hold that men fight (or in this case, are ready to fight) not for causes, but to survive and to help their comrades do the same.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Jarhead is often a film about boredom, but it's never boring; full of unexpected touches and detailed character turns.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The invigorating thing about Jarhead is it makes us encounter the truth in its undigested form.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As hard as the actors work, Jarhead feels false right down to its seductive visuals.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Gyllenhaal is the heart and soul of a darkly funny and ferociously intense movie that sets its sights on soldiers under the gun of doing nothing.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Although the picture suffers a narrative letdown in the third act that leaves its central characters -- and, alas, its audience -- in the muck of anticlimax, Jarhead has moments of real glory.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Jarhead can't shoot its way out of its own cliches.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie is so good you wish it were even better, particularly in its characterizations.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Do I quibble over details? Details are all the movie offers.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie has some of the washed-out look of David O. Russell's excellent Three Kings, but none of the edge.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The people you feel most badly for in Jarhead are not the men played by these talented actors, but the marketing department at Universal Pictures, saddled with the impossible task of selling a war movie that doesn't contain any actual war in it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I dare anyone to watch this bold exercise in postponed gratification and not come away with a new, disturbed sense of the genre.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A war picture that, trying to pass off fidelity to the book as objectivity, sacrifices any voice of its own, and ends up not knowing what to think.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Nicely acted, beautifully shot and pretty much devoid of action and context, Jarhead has to be considered one of the year's biggest failures, simply because so much talent went into a film so empty.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Great fun, as these things go, with a Bernard Herrmann score to boot.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: A protracted and only sporadically imaginative menu of ways to be murdered.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie is concocted and carried out by folks worthy of scorn, and the nicest thing I can say is that I can't remember a single name responsible for it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As we have come to learn -- as many times as we have fingers to count on -- Jason is a killer who doesn't know the meaning of the word 'quit.' The filmmakers might want to look it up.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: The acting rarely surpasses the occasional sexy hair-toss.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: The producers of this film, which depicts teen-age girls as an assemblage of negative stereotypes, are female. Can females practice misogyny?

item.label: rotten
item.content: Only the soundtrack (the Donnas, Imperial Teen) and the irrepressible McGowan make it fractionally more bearable.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's a tired lousy movie, a terrible twosome that deserves your heartfelt indifference.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: Not enough here that's new.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A synthetic yet shrill sadomasochistic cartoon!

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: Imitative of Heathers, but not nearly as witty or engaging.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Jawbreaker may promise a series of gleefully cheap thrills, but in the end all it delivers is a whole lot of bad taste.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: A slick production of a lame script!

item.label: rotten
item.content: One-liners tumble over one another, dulling their own impact. Plot points hurl from the screen with velocity, but fizzle from a lack of inspiration.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The lowest piece of garbage to hit screens in months.

item.label: fresh
item.content: When it comes to this kind of thriller, no movie has been able to top Jaws, although many have tried. And, as the years go by, it seems increasingly unlikely that anything will come close.

item.label: fresh
item.content: One of the most effective thrillers ever made.

item.content: It's mostly just a matter of waiting till feeding time.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mild and predictable, the very things an adventure movie should never be.

item.content: After Steven Spielberg's original, which combined shock effects with comedy and grand sea adventure touches, the series has degenerated into your basic fish-bites-man story, with very few imaginative wrinkles.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The shark models have so little movement that at times they seem to be supporting themselves on boats, instead of attacking them. Up until the ludicrous final sequence of the movie, the scariest creature in the film is an eel.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Has the lazy, bric-a-brac atmosphere of one of those blown-off movies made during down time on some bigger affair.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The perfect curtain call for these much-loved, wise but oh so stupid slackers.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I admit to enjoying -- in a drunken, half-asleep kind of way -- parts of this ramshackle road movie with its running Miramax guest stars and its endless homo jokes.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Smith, coming off the madly audacious Dogma, knows that he's slumming this time and revels in it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The picture lacks the mix of innocence and savagery that branded [Smith's] other films.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In keeping with the Smith rules, the movie is irreverent, self-referential, twisted, cheap and tasteless. And, of course, I mean that as the highest compliment.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In addition to being [Smith's] filthiest, this is his most free-associative movie. In spite of and because of its homemade look, it's also his funniest.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A desperate attempt by Kevin Smith to pay homage to himself in a self-consciously left-handed way.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A dumbfounding, cameo-peppered road comedy that demeans everyone associated with it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The originality and intelligence that made Smith's Clerks and Chasing Amy such refreshing pleasures are all but absent.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The relentless torrent of foul language--and not just from Jay--becomes numbing and finally makes the film seem more crass than amusing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Not clever enough for Smith fans, not gross enough to compete on the Farrelly brothers' ground, the movie feels like a kind of self-congratulatory fake.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Deliciously inane, transcendentally outrageous and purposely preposterous, Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back is destined to be seen by some as the greatest cinematic achievement of the year.

item.label: fresh
item.content: While Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back can't be called hard-hitting, it's both freeform enough and free-swinging enough to make contact with the series' original anarchic impulses.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This ramshackle affair unspools like a bloopers reel of stag-party outtakes culled from Smith's four previous movies: Clerks, Mallrats, Chasing Amy and Dogma.

item.label: fresh
item.content: All that's required to enjoy this crazily engaging comedy is to be somewhere near Smith's twisted Gen X wavelength.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: The point of the film is not to create suspense, but to capture the relentlessness of human greed, the feeling that the land is so important the human spirit can be sacrificed to it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You may also become permanently sick of goats. But after Jean, a rich residue of themes and images remains -- much as after reading a long but great novel or Greek tragedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Jeanne Dielman is immersion cinema, a brilliant example of maximal minimalism that fuses viewer with subject so profoundly, the marathon experience transcends simple spectatorship.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Chantal Akerman's feature is one of the few 'feminist' movies that's as interesting aesthetically as politically.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Jeanne Dielman deals in unadorned facts. It's about the looks and sounds of ordinary things and people, which it records with such... unsettling clarity that it has the effect of finding threats in mundane objects and doom in [the] commonplace.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Akerman forges a major statement, not only in a feminist context but also in a way that tells us something about the lives we all live.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: Usually the tautest of directors, Clint Eastwood has gone all slack here, allowing his subject to get completely away from him.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Although Hoover's luster faded as his career went on, Eastwood's movie seems wan from the start.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Here's that J. Edgar Hoover biopic you asked for, or at least something that meets all the technical requirements to be considered one.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mr. Eastwood's ponderous direction, a clumsy script by Dustin Lance Black and ghastly slatherings of old-age makeup all conspire to put the story at an emotional and historical distance. It's a partially animated waxworks.

item.label: fresh
item.content: How believable is DiCaprio? When I first heard he had been cast as Hoover, I couldn't think of another actor physically less likely to pull it off. But he's surprisingly good.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Within the sprawling biopic that is J. Edgar beats the heart of a love story.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For all its virtues -- or, perhaps, because of them -- J. Edgar is a disappointment.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This far-from-perfect film is hobbled by uneven performances and a script studded with historical bullet points. But it's a strong tribute to Eastwood's personal vision.

item.label: rotten
item.content: J. Edgar is an arduous trek through the history books, a gloomy glide down the marble halls of a Washington institution.

item.label: rotten
item.content: That \"J. Edgar'' never ultimately convinces - that at times it's quite entertainingly bad - can be blamed on both an unfocused script and the project's very bigness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [DiCaprio] digs into the role of Hoover with relish and commitment

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"J. Edgar\" too often feels like the rough draft of the great movie it could have been; a character sketch, not quite a portrait.

item.label: fresh
item.content: DiCaprio wrings truth out of a cipher. The Hoover of both headline and whispers comes into sharp relief in this Oscar-beckoning performance.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Whether unintentionally or by design, the movie never really makes a case either for or against the troubled figure at its center.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This may be a closety film about a closety character, but the tensions between Eastwood's direction and the script he's directing keep us off-guard in an intriguing way. The results, whatever one thinks of them, may be square, but they're all of a piece.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Eastwood, forsaking his deliberate rhythms for something speedier and wordier, turns J. Edgar into a dramatic essay about how the law and repression, heroism and corruption, fused in Hoover.

item.content: I think there's a reason they're a no name cast. There's not really anybody that's really very identifiable, or very good in their roles.

item.content: It's gory, repetitive, and not terribly interesting.

item.content: Functional but tiresome.

item.content: A stark regression from the intelligence of the Scream franchise, this teen horror sequel is about as satisfying as low-budget food that's been under the heat lamps too long.

item.content: The lives of these sweet, confused, basically decent people wrap around one another in ways that are funny, far-fetched and touching.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's the modest, mumblecore version of the seemingly perennial story of man-children in the promised land.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a brilliant sleight of hand: Nothing important seems to be happening, and yet stuff keeps happening, and the movie is always pushing forward.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sarandon is worth leaving home for, even if Jeff won't.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You come to like Jeff and even to admire him. The aura of holy foolishness that hangs around him is not just bong exhaust: he turns out to be the hero of a disarmingly sincere spiritual fable.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Most of the material avoids the treacle zone, while Jason Segel, as the man-child in residence, gives a performance that I can only describe as gravely affecting.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Jeff, Who Lives at Home\" has a meandering quality, like its title, that's oddly appealing; you feel like you know these very regular-looking people, and slowly become invested in their dilemmas.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Both Jeff and the film have a way of sneaking up on you.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It feels incomplete and the ending is entirely too convenient. We've seen all of this before.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The plausibility of the finale is open to question, but the filmmaking duo's determination to take us there makes a nice kind of sense.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For both Segel and the Duplass brothers, Jeff marks a turning point. The actor comes into his own with a layered, pleasing performance, and the filmmakers behind The Puffy Chair, Baghead and Cyrus move towards more commercial films.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A surprisingly sappy misfire from brothers Jay and Mark Duplass - a hug-it-out, touchy-feely movie that succumbs to the maudlin sentimentality they had avoided in all their previous pictures.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This latest comedy from writer-directors Jay and Mark Duplass turns out to be chock-full of an element missing from most of today's movies: genuine surprise.

item.content: By tapping in to the same vein of 'hormonal horror' as the excellent 'Ginger Snaps', this offers a witty, subversive look at the darker side of teen friendship.

item.content: There are probably worse ways to go out than being devoured by Fox... but the film squanders all the fun from what could have been a hilarious, gore-filled romp.

item.content: Director Karyn Kusama finds resonant terror in details: the look Anita and Jennifer exchange before Jen's fateful ride, or a victim's last-minute ah-hah.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a fun premise -- a twist on the usual girl-in-distress scenario of the standard-issue horror film -- enlivened by Codyspeak.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [T]here's something a bit sour about the whole enterprise, a lack of fun that becomes more evident as the injuries and indignities piled upon poor Needy accumulate, and gradually crowd out the film's early tongue-in-cheekiness.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The tone wavers, the direction's slackly indecisive and visually drab, and in the middle of it is a thinly conceived antagonist played by Megan Fox. Honestly, she's a pretty bad actress. She doesn't seem to get Cody's sense of humor. At all.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Jennifer's Body falls into the dispiriting category of dumb movies made by smart people, in this case a glibly clever writer and a talented director who think a few wisecracks are enough to subvert the teen horror genre.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The amateurishly directed 'Jennifer's Body' is a bust as ha-ha horror movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I'd like to see Jennifer get transferred to that \"Twilight\" school and stir up some trouble.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie substitutes calculation for brains, and the filmmakers seem to think we'll all be too stupid to notice.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Its] depiction of the ways in which women like Needy are willing to compromise themselves to indulge an ultimately less secure friend is spot-on.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Jennifer's Body comes across as Diablo Cody lite, something she seems to have dashed off in-between talk show appearances and updating her MySpace page with her latest caustic witticisms.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: As a horror movie, Jennifer's Body doesn't fully deliver. But as a comic allegory of what it's like to be an adolescent girl who comes into sexual and social power that she doesn't know what the heck to do with, it is a minor classic.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Even though Fearless is laced with stunning fight sequences, none of them have lingered in my memory as vividly as Li's face has: His body may begin the story told in Fearless, but his face completes it.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: After its soaring beginning, Guardians of Ga'Hoole plummets to more generic ground. It's well-made, but how can you care about its owl heroes and villains when you can't always tell them apart?

item.label: rotten
item.content: The effect finally is to neglect, rather than nurture, a story with potential.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Becker ably milks the premise for irony and amusement.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: It is not a step-by-step chronicle of German reunification, but it gives a perspective of the time. It's a bonus that this comes as part of an engrossing and well told story.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Combination of comedy and gravity is certainly common enough, but it requires a sure hand and perceptible intent. This screenplay has some neat touches, but it never makes up its mind.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Beneath the family saga and easy digs at the tackiness of Western consumer culture, Becker presents a serious critique of authoritarianism and propaganda.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Becker handles the film's comedy with fluency ... but he's even better when it comes to the story's more wistful dramatic elements.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Anyone who has ever longed for the good ol' days -- even the ones that weren't so good -- will find resonance in this well-told and well-acted parable of family and political unification.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A film that's ostensibly about politics ... turns out to be a love story.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's mainly a hunt for ironies, usually playful but occasionally poignant, and the search is definitely successful enough to merit our attention -- although maybe not the two-hour running time.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Melville's eye for exacting detail here is expected. What is remarkable is the depth of feeling he exacts from the juxtaposition of these ordinary moments with their extraordinary context.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a giddy bit of blasphemy to see Jean-Paul Belmondo dressed in priest's garb.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The result is a movie that moves with the diamond-cut precision and carefully constricting tension of Melville's trademark gangland sagas, the precious booty here being nothing less than the human soul.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Miraculous cinema, even for heretics.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Not an unqualified success, the film remains strong for its performances, its inventive editing and framing, and its evocative rendering of the French occupation.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Melville's film had a major influence in Hollywood.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Melville's] style remains haunting and elegantly spare, just right for the kind of hit man who lives in silence, in bare and colorless surroundings, with a lonely caged bird.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Le samourai expresses a kind of loneliness to be sure, but it's that of a teenage male dreaming about Hollywood movies and their accoutrements -- penthouse apartments, acerbic cops, melancholy city streets, smoky card games, fancy jazz nightclubs.

item.label: fresh
item.content: One of the pleasures of Le Samourai is to realize how complicated the plot has grown, in its flat, deadpan way.

item.label: fresh
item.content: To each his own. Filmmakers as diverse as Quentin Tarantino and Paul Schrader were influenced by Melville, and Hong Kong action director John Woo calls the film 'the closest to a perfect movie that I have ever seen.'

item.label: fresh
item.content: It combines stylish direction, an intelligent script, first-rate performances, and overpowering atmosphere into one of the most tense and absorbing thrillers ever to reach the screen.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: It carries some interest in its curious blend of tones and styles -- it oscillates between vaudeville turns and stark tragedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Renoir sought out balance and humanistic sympathy, reshaping the narrative so the thief (Jean Gabin) and the Baron (Louis Jouvet) bond over their mutual rebellion against the social system.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Agreeably goofy but surprisingly mild horror-comedy...that's several guffaws short of a laff riot.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Concise progression, fine technical aspects, and the look at innocence destroyed by the profane keeps it absorbing, despite the slightly pretentious treatment at times.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A fine, richly detailed tableau of student life in Paris, and Chabrol's first statement (in his second film) of his sardonic view of life as a matter of the survival of the fittest.

item.label: fresh
item.content: M. Chabrol has more skill with the camera than he has with the pen, and his picture is more credible to the eye than it is to the skeptical mind. But it is not the less overwhelming.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is Chabrol's second film, and its subtle development of character points toward the dense structures of his later films with their reluctance either to condemn or extol without reservation.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sexuality takes precedence over salvation, but there is the same interiority, the same intensity, the same rigorous exclusion of all inessentials.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It is slow, solemn, rigidly conventional and as stilted as a silent film, but it shows Bresson's early ability to catch sober and smoldering moods with his camera.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Like much (if not all) of Bresson's best work, it can't be assimilated to realist criteria, but it's unforgettable for its fire-and-ice evocations of tragedy in an unlikely setting.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Although this has a few hallucinating bits of terror, the film is primarily a creaky-door type of melodrama.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Cruel, sour, and -- unfortunately -- very effective.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A great piece of Guignol misanthropy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is one of the dandiest mystery dramas that has shown here in goodness knows when.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Creates] a diabolical double-reverse plot that keeps the audience guessing right up to the thoroughly implausible final scene.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With a deliciously curvy and complex plot, Diabolique is a masterpiece of suspense -- as accomplished as anything done by Hitchcock.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Jean Cocteau has written the pic and delivers the commentary, which creates a gripping, dream-like attraction.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Filmed in the most daring way imaginable, using a new cinematic language of transient expressions and glances, the film was a root influence on Bresson and the whole French New Wave.

item.label: fresh

item.content: Hooper's 'Les Miserables': Bloated anti-musical

item.label: rotten
item.content: Fans of the original production, no doubt, will eat the movie up, and good luck to them. I screamed a scream as time went by.

item.label: fresh
item.content: ... Jackman, who should get a Nobel Prize for the way he carries pretty much the whole undertaking on his shoulders, so protean and virile is his singing and acting throughout.

item.label: rotten
item.content: At the heart of the \"Les Miserables\" movie was a good idea that just didn't work out this time. The idea was that the actors should sing their songs live on camera.

item.label: rotten
item.content: We're all familiar with the experience of seeing movies that cram ideas and themes down our throats. Les Miserables may represent the first movie to do so while also cramming us down the throats of its actors.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Committed fans of the musical are likely to have their affections reaffirmed. The less devout, however, may conclude that in this case more is less, and fidelity not always a virtue.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It lives in that kinda-sorta, okay-not-great, this-worked-that-didn't in-between for which words like \"better\" and \"worse\" fall woefully short.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If you like your musicals enormous, over the top and bang-on-the-head manipulative, \"Les Miserables\" is the movie for you.

item.label: rotten
item.content: By the grand finale, when tout le monde is waving the French tricolor in victory, you may instead be raising the white flag in exhausted defeat.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.content: It's fun stuff -- crackling, playfully escapist summer fare that doesn't make you feel taken advantage of later.

item.label: fresh
item.content: They know what they're doing and how to do it, but we miss the sense of invention that brightened the earlier movies.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If there's an original moment in this movie, producer Joel Silver and director Richard Donner sincerely apologize.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Yes, there is a shot of Mel Gibson's bum, and, no, director-producer Richard Donner still hasn't learned the first thing about directing action so that it has any coherence or beauty.
